name: Color Game
smallText: This is a small vanila javascript game. In the header engine gives us the RGB code. In the middle we have 6 squares colored in random colors. We have to guess what color is set in the header. We can change difficult. If we choice hard we will get six square of colors. On easy we will get three square, and the game will be significantly easy. On button new colors we generate new colors in square and header.

text.name: h2
text.content: This is a small vanila javascript game.

text.name: p
text.content: In the header engine gives us the RGB code. In the middle we have 6 squares colored in random colors. We have to guess what color is set in the header.

text.name: images
text.content: data:image/jpeg;base64,

text.name: h4
text.content: Difficult

text.name: p
text.content: We can change difficult. If we choice hard we will get six square of colors. On easy we will get three square, and the game will be significantly easy. On button new colors we generate new colors in square and header.

text.name: images
text.content: data:image/jpeg;base64,

text.name: h4
text.content: Rules

text.name: p
text.content: We have to click on the squares and try to guess what color is represented on the header. If we give the wrong answer square will disappear.

text.name: images
text.content: data:image/jpeg;base64,

text.name: p
text.content: But if we give the right answer, all disappear squares will come back, but now the color of squares will be color of header. Also background of the header will be that color. After that,  you can on button new color generate other colors and play the game again.

text.name: images
text.content: data:image/jpeg;base64,

text.name: h2
text.content: Webpack

text.name: p
text.content: As I said, this is a pure Javascript project. I use Webpack for bundling projects. For CSS preprocessing I use sass. Here is all npm dependency.

text.name: code
text.content:
{
    "name": "colorgame",
    "version": "1.0.0",
    "description": "",
    "main": "index.js",
    "scripts": {
        "build": "webpack",
        "dev": "webpack-dev-server"
    },
    "author": "",
    "license": "ISC",
    "dependencies": {
        "@babel/core": "^7.5.5",
        "@babel/preset-env": "^7.5.5",
        "babel-core": "^6.26.3",
        "babel-loader": "^8.0.6",
        "babel-preset-env": "^1.7.0",
        "css-loader": "^3.1.0",
        "file-loader": "^4.1.0",
        "html-loader": "^0.5.5",
        "html-webpack-plugin": "^3.2.0",
        "mini-css-extract-plugin": "^0.8.0",
        "node-sass": "^4.12.0",
        "sass-loader": "^7.1.0",
        "style-loader": "^0.23.1",
        "webpack": "^4.36.1",
        "webpack-cli": "^3.3.6",
        "webpack-dev-server": "^3.7.2"
    }
}

text.name: h4
text.content: Webpack setup

text.name: p
text.content: Here are all webpack settings. I use two plugins. One is HtmlWebPackPlugin and the second one is MiniCssExtractPlugin.

text.name: code
text.content:
const HtmlWebPackPlugin = require('html-webpack-plugin');
const MiniCssExtractPlugin = require('mini-css-extract-plugin');

text.name: p
text.content: I set up rules for BABEL, HTML, Asset (for image) and SCSS.

text.name: code
text.content:
module.exports = {
    mode: 'production',
    module: {
        rules: [
            // babel rules
            {
                test: /.m?js$/,
                exclude: /(node_modules|bower_components)/,
                use: {
                    loader: 'babel-loader',
                    options: {
                        presets: [ '@babel/preset-env' ]
                    }
                }
            },

            // html rules
            {
                test: /.html$/,
                use: [
                    {
                        loader: 'html-loader',
                        options: { minimized: true }
                    }
                ]
            },

            // asset rules
            {
                test: /.(png|jpe?g|gif)$/,
                use: [
                    {
                        loader: 'file-loader',
                        options: {}
                    }
                ]
            },

            // scss rules
            {
                test: /.scss$/,
                use: [ 'style-loader', 'css-loader', 'sass-loader' ]
            }
        ]
    },

text.name: p
text.content: And at last, I use HtmlWebPackPlugin and MiniCssExtractPlugin plugins.

text.name: code
text.content:
plugins: [
        new HtmlWebPackPlugin({
            template: './src/index.html',
            filename: './index.html'
        }),
        new MiniCssExtractPlugin({
            filename: '[name].css',
            chunkFilename: '[id].css'
        })
    ]

text.name: h2
text.content: Code and logic

text.name: p
text.content: I chose here prototype inheritance logic. Basically the whole project consists of one central App.js module and 3 hooks module which are located in folder hooks.

text.name: images
text.content: data:image/jpeg;base64,

text.name: h4
text.content: App.js

text.name: p
text.content: App.js is the main module. In this module, I invoke all secondary modules. At the top of the module, I import hooks for dom manipulation, global prototype methods and clicks events hooks. Here is happen nothing special. Its only import and invoke imported.

text.name: code
text.content:
import useDom from './hooks/useDom';
import useGlobalProto from './hooks/useGlobalProto';
import useClickEvent from './hooks/useClickEvent';

const { dom } = useDom();
useGlobalProto();
const { difficult, newColor } = useClickEvent();

dom.createBoxes();
dom.colorBoxes();
dom.headerGenerateColor();
difficult.call(dom);
newColor.call(dom);

text.name: h4
text.content: UseDom.js

text.name: p
text.content: This is the module where I doing manipulation with dom.  Here we have useDom hook which is the main dom function, wich one will return created dom object with selected elements and methods.

text.name: code
text.content:
const useDom = () => {
    function Dom(boxesParent, newColor, btns, headerColor, header, menuMessage) {
        this.boxesParent = boxesParent;
        this.newColor = newColor;
        this.btns = btns;
        this.headerColor = headerColor;
        this.header = header;
        this.menuMessage = menuMessage;
    }

    Dom.prototype.createBoxes = function(btn) {
        this.boxesParent.innerHTML = '';
        let counter = 6;
        if (btn && btn.getAttribute('data-difficult') === 'easy') {
            counter = 3;
        }

        for (let i = 0; i < counter; i++) {
            this.boxesParent.innerHTML += '<div class="content__box"></div>';
        }
    };

    Dom.prototype.colorBoxes = function() {
        this.header.style.background = '#4581B3';
        Object.colors.length = 0;
        [ ...this.boxesParent.children ].forEach((item, index) => {
            const color = Object.color();
            Object.colors.push(color);
            item.style.background = color;
            item.onclick = Object.checkClickedColor.bind(dom, index, item);
        });
    };

    Dom.prototype.headerGenerateColor = function() {
        this.headerColor.textContent = Object.colorHeader();
    };

    const dom = new Dom(
        document.querySelector('.content__boxes'),
        document.querySelector('.menu__h2'),
        [ ...document.querySelector('.menu__ul').children ],
        document.querySelector('.header__color'),
        document.querySelector('.header'),
        document.querySelector('.menu__message')
    );

    return { dom };
};

export default useDom;

text.name: h5
text.content: Function constructor Dom

text.name: p
text.content: At the top, we have one function constructor which one serves to create one main dom object. That object will contain all elements which we wanna be select.

text.name: code
text.content:
function Dom(boxesParent, newColor, btns, headerColor, header, menuMessage) {
        this.boxesParent = boxesParent;
        this.newColor = newColor;
        this.btns = btns;
        this.headerColor = headerColor;
        this.header = header;
        this.menuMessage = menuMessage;
    }

text.name: h5
text.content: CreateBoxes methods

text.name: p
text.content: Create a Box method that has a purpose to dynamically create color boxes when the game start. Also, change the difficulty between three or six square. When we call this method it immediately destroys old HTML elements and generate a new one.

text.name: code
text.content:
Dom.prototype.createBoxes = function(btn) {
        this.boxesParent.innerHTML = '';
        let counter = 6;
        if (btn && btn.getAttribute('data-difficult') === 'easy') {
            counter = 3;
        }

        for (let i = 0; i < counter; i++) {
            this.boxesParent.innerHTML += '<div class="content__box"></div>';
        }
    };

text.name: h5
text.content: ColorBoxes methods

text.name: p
text.content: This method paints a header background when we need to reset it to default after finish a game and reset global colors array to zero. Also looping through all squares generate one color per loop and that color push into global colors array.  Also current square paint in that color. At the and create click event on that square.

text.name: code
text.content:
Dom.prototype.colorBoxes = function() {
        this.header.style.background = '#4581B3';
        Object.colors.length = 0;
        [ ...this.boxesParent.children ].forEach((item, index) => {
            const color = Object.color();
            Object.colors.push(color);
            item.style.background = color;
            item.onclick = Object.checkClickedColor.bind(dom, index, item);
        });
    };

text.name: h5
text.content: HeaderGenerateColor methods

text.name: p
text.content: This is a simple but very helpful method. It takes from the global method generated color and writes it to the HTML in RGB code format.

text.name: code
text.content:
Dom.prototype.headerGenerateColor = function() {
        this.headerColor.textContent = Object.colorHeader();
    };

text.name: h5
text.content: Dom object

text.name: p
text.content: In the end, we create a dom object wich one contain all methods and elements which we create.

text.name: code
text.content:
const dom = new Dom(
        document.querySelector('.content__boxes'),
        document.querySelector('.menu__h2'),
        [ ...document.querySelector('.menu__ul').children ],
        document.querySelector('.header__color'),
        document.querySelector('.header'),
        document.querySelector('.menu__message')
    );

text.name: h4
text.content: UseGlobalProto.js

text.name: p
text.content: This module contains variables and methods which one created with the main Object constructor and there are located at the end of the prototype chain. These methods are available for all methods in this prototype chain.

text.name: code
text.content:
const useGlobalProto = () => {
    Object.prototype.colors = [];

    //generate random color
    Object.prototype.color = () =>
        `RGB(${Math.floor(Math.random() * 255)}, ${Math.floor(Math.random() * 255)}, ${Math.floor(
            Math.random() * 255
        )})`;

    // generate color for header
    Object.prototype.colorHeader = () => colors[Math.floor(Math.random() * colors.length)];

    //Clicked color check
    Object.prototype.checkClickedColor = function(index, box) {
        if (Object.colors[index] === this.headerColor.textContent) {
            this.header.style.background = this.headerColor.textContent;
            [ ...this.boxesParent.children ].forEach((item) => {
                item.style.background = this.headerColor.textContent;
                item.style.opacity = "1";
                item.onclick = null;
                this.menuMessage.textContent = "Correct!";
            });
        } else {
            box.style.opacity = "0";
            this.menuMessage.textContent = "Try Again...";
        }
    };
};

export default useGlobalProto;

text.name: h5
text.content: Object.prototype.colors

text.name: p
text.content: This is simple empty array. His purpose is to keep the generated colors. He must be global because all program needs to use these colors.

text.name: code
text.content: Object.prototype.colors = [];

text.name: h5
text.content: Object.prototype.color

text.name: p
text.content: This is the method which one generate RGB color. When we create all boxes, we call colorBoxes method, where we invoke this method to generate colors for that box. So this is the main method for creating colors.

text.name: code
text.content:
Object.prototype.color = () =>
        `RGB(${Math.floor(Math.random() * 255)}, ${Math.floor(Math.random() * 255)}, ${Math.floor(
            Math.random() * 255
        )})`;

text.name: h5
text.content: Object.prototype.colorHeader

text.name: p
text.content: When we are done with creating boxes, we have to generate a header color. That color is unique and important for checking do we or not plug the right color. This method does that.

text.name: code
text.content: Object.prototype.colorHeader = () => colors[Math.floor(Math.random() * colors.length)];

text.name: h5
text.content: Object.prototype.checkClickedColor

text.name: p
text.content: Here we are on maybe the most important method in this program. Here we check our answer. We compare the clicked color and header color. if comparison true, we colorized all heder in generated color. Then we loop through all boxes and colorized boxes in that color. if is the answer false, method set opacity of box to 0 and write 'Try Again' message.

text.name: code
text.content:
Object.prototype.checkClickedColor = function(index, box) {
        if (Object.colors[index] === this.headerColor.textContent) {
            this.header.style.background = this.headerColor.textContent;
            [ ...this.boxesParent.children ].forEach((item) => {
                item.style.background = this.headerColor.textContent;
                item.style.opacity = "1";
                item.onclick = null;
                this.menuMessage.textContent = "Correct!";
            });
        } else {
            box.style.opacity = "0";
            this.menuMessage.textContent = "Try Again...";
        }
    };

text.name: h4
text.content: UseClickEvent.js

text.name: p
text.content: This model contains two methods that set up a click event.

text.name: code
text.content:
const useClickEvent = () => {
    const difficult = function() {
        this.btns.forEach((item) => {
            item.onclick = () => {
                this.createBoxes(item);
                this.colorBoxes();
                this.headerGenerateColor();
            };
        });
    };

    const newColor = function() {
        this.newColor.onclick = () => {
            this.colorBoxes();
            this.headerGenerateColor();
        };
    };

    return { difficult, newColor };
};

export default useClickEvent;

text.name: h5
text.content: Function Difficult

text.name: p
text.content: This method set up click event on difficult buttons. That click event calls a function that calls the method for creating and coloring squares, and the method that generates the color of the header.

text.name: code
text.content:
const difficult = function() {
        this.btns.forEach((item) => {
            item.onclick = () => {
                this.createBoxes(item);
                this.colorBoxes();
                this.headerGenerateColor();
            };
        });
    };

text.name: h5
text.content: Function NewColor

text.name: p
text.content: Here we have a method that sets a click event to a newColor button. That click event calls a function that calls the method that colors the squares and the method that generates the color of the header.

text.name: code
text.content:
const newColor = function() {
        this.newColor.onclick = () => {
            this.colorBoxes();
            this.headerGenerateColor();
        };
    };

text.name: h2
text.content: React Js

text.name: p
text.content: I also did a version done in the React Js framework. There is a lot less code. We have only three modules.

text.name: images
text.content: data:image/jpeg;base64,

text.name: h4
text.content: ColorGame.js

text.name: p
text.content: I don't use class anymore, I use hooks logic. In this app use three native hooks, useState, useEffect and useRef. Also, I create two custom hook, useBox and useSelect.

text.name: code
text.content:
import React, { useState, useEffect, useRef } from "react";

//hooks
import useBox from "./useBox";
import useSelect from "./useSelect";

const ColorGame = () => {
    const header = useRef();
    const headerColor = useRef();
    const contentBoxes = useRef();
    const menuUl = useRef();
    const [ box, setBox ] = useState([]);
    const [ counter, setCounter ] = useState(6);
    const { difficult } = useBox(setBox, headerColor, header, contentBoxes);
    const { select } = useSelect();

    const easy = (e) => {
        setCounter(3);
        select(menuUl, e);
    };

    const hard = (e) => {
        setCounter(6);
        select(menuUl, e);
    };

    useEffect(
        () => {
            difficult(counter);
        },
        [ counter ]
    );

    return (
        <div className="colorgame">
            <div className="colorgame__header" ref={header}>
                <h1 className="colorgame__header__h1">THE GREAT</h1>
                <p className="colorgame__header__color" ref={headerColor} />
                <p className="colorgame__header__p">COLOR GAME</p>
            </div>
            <div className="colorgame__menu">
                <h2 className="colorgame__menu__h2" onClick={difficult.bind(null, counter)}>
                    NEW COLORS
                </h2>
                <p className="colorgame__menu__message" />
                <ul className="colorgame__menu__ul" ref={menuUl}>
                    <li className="colorgame__menu__li" onClick={easy}>
                        EASY
                    </li>
                    <li className="colorgame__menu__li colorgame__active" onClick={hard}>
                        HARD
                    </li>
                </ul>
            </div>
            <div className="colorgame__content">
                <div className="colorgame__content__boxes" ref={contentBoxes}>
                    {box.map((item) => {
                        return item;
                    })}
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
    );
};

export default ColorGame;

text.name: h5
text.content: Easy and Hard functions

text.name: p
text.content: This too functions is for set difficult. They don't do anything special but they are it's very important. These two functions invoke set counter hooks and set the number of squares. One important thing is they trigger render. When counter state change useEffect  call difficult method from custom hook.

text.name: code
text.content:
const easy = (e) => {
        setCounter(3);
        select(menuUl, e);
    };

    const hard = (e) => {
        setCounter(6);
        select(menuUl, e);
    };

    useEffect(
        () => {
            difficult(counter);
        },
        [ counter ]
    );

text.name: h4
text.content: UseBox.js

text.name: p
text.content: This is the custom hook. All logic of app doing here.

text.name: code
text.content:
import React from "react";

const useBox = (setBox, headerColor, header, contentBoxes) => {
    const boxes = [];
    const colors = [];
    let headerRgb = ;

    const testColor = (e) => {
        if (e.target.style.background === headerRgb) {
            header.current.style.background = headerRgb;
            [ ...contentBoxes.current.children ].forEach((item) => {
                item.style.opacity = 1;
                item.style.background = headerRgb;
            });
        } else {
            e.target.style.opacity = 0;
        }
    };

    const difficult = (counter) => {
        header.current.style.background = "#4581B3";

        for (let i = 0; i < counter; i++) {
            const color = `rgb(${Math.floor(Math.random() * 255)}, ${Math.floor(Math.random() * 255)}, ${Math.floor(
                Math.random() * 255
            )})`;
            colors.push(color);
            boxes.push(
                <div
                    key={i}
                    className="colorgame__content__box"
                    style={{ background: color, opacity: 1 }}
                    onClick={testColor}
                />
            );
        }
        setBox(boxes);
        if (headerColor.current) {
            headerRgb = headerColor.current.textContent = colors[Math.floor(Math.random() * colors.length)];
        }
        return headerRgb;
    };

    return { difficult };
};

export default useBox;

text.name: h5
text.content: Difficult method

text.name: p
text.content: This method gets counter-argument from the counter state. First setup header background. We get the header element with Ref. Then we make one for loop. As a counter, we took the created counter from state. Below we have const color where we generate color. Then that color push in colors array. And on the end on the fly we setup div (JSX) with className, style, key prop, onClick event, and push it in boxes array. Then set Box state with that boxes array. This state will be rendered on the main page with other JSX. At the end of this method, we generate header color and this method will return that color as a result.

text.name: code
text.content:
const difficult = (counter) => {
        header.current.style.background = "#4581B3";

        for (let i = 0; i < counter; i++) {
            const color = `rgb(${Math.floor(Math.random() * 255)}, ${Math.floor(Math.random() * 255)}, ${Math.floor(
                Math.random() * 255
            )})`;
            colors.push(color);
            boxes.push(
                <div
                    key={i}
                    className="colorgame__content__box"
                    style={{ background: color, opacity: 1 }}
                    onClick={testColor}
                />
            );
        }
        setBox(boxes);
        if (headerColor.current) {
            headerRgb = headerColor.current.textContent = colors[Math.floor(Math.random() * colors.length)];
        }
        return headerRgb;
    };

text.name: h5
text.content: TestColor method

text.name: p
text.content: This is a simple method for testing our answer. Method take clicked target-style background and compare it with generated header color. if we gave the correct answer, method take header (we got header element with Ref) and colorized in generated header color. Then we use spread syntax to get all boxes from boxes parent (also we got parent from Ref) in one array, and set opacity on 1 and background color on header color. Else we just set target opacity on 0.

text.name: code
text.content:
const testColor = (e) => {
        if (e.target.style.background === headerRgb) {
            header.current.style.background = headerRgb;
            [ ...contentBoxes.current.children ].forEach((item) => {
                item.style.opacity = 1;
                item.style.background = headerRgb;
            });
        } else {
            e.target.style.opacity = 0;
        }
    };

text.content: UseSelect.js

text.name: p
text.content: This is a little hook. His job is to change the active class on easy and hard buttons.

text.name: code
text.content:
const useSelect = () => {
    const select = (menuUl, e) => {
        [ ...menuUl.current.children ].forEach((item) => {
            item.style.background = "white";
            item.style.color = "#4581B3";
        });
        e.target.style.background = "#4581B3";
        e.target.style.color = "white";
    };

    return { select };
};

export default useSelect;
